sentence: Shares of salesforce.com Inc.CRM gained over 6% in afterhours trading session yesterday on strong first-quarter fiscal 2017 results, wherein its top line beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate, while the bottom line matched the same.
An optimistic outlook for the second quarter and upbeat guidance for fiscal 2017 further boosted investor confidence.

The company reported adjusted earnings (including stock-based compensation but excluding all one-time items on a proportionate tax basis) of 8 cents per share, which was in line with the Zacks Consensus Estimate.
Moreover, the figure was a four-fold jump year over year.
On GAAP basis, Salesforce's earnings came in at 6 cents per share, compared with earnings of a penny in the first quarter of fiscal 2016.
The robust performance was mainly driven by strong top-line growth and stringent cost management.
Salesforce's revenues of $1.917 billion not only increased 26.8% year over year, but also beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.889 billion.
Moreover, reported revenues came above management's guided range of $1.885 billion to $1.895 billion.
The improvement is primarily attributable to rapid adoption of the company's cloud-based solutions.
Also, higher demand for the Salesforce ExactTarget Marketing Cloud platform, part of the Salesforce1 Customer Platform, drove the year-over-year upside in revenues.
During the quarter, the company's cloud-based solutions were selected by a number of companies including Amazon AMZN , Uber, Samsung, New York Life and several other leading companies in Europe.
Among its business segments, revenues at Subscription and Support surged 26.3% from the year-ago quarter to $1.775 billion.
Professional Services and Other revenues jumped 33.3% to $141.1 million.
Geographically, the company witnessed revenue growth of 27%, 33% and 29% in the Americas, Europe and Asia, respectively, on a year-over-year basis.
Salesforce's adjusted gross profit (including stock-based compensation but excluding amortization expenses) came in at $1.442 billion, up 25.3%.
However, gross margin contracted 80 basis points (bps) to 75.2%, primarily due to increased investment in infrastructure development, including the expansion of the international data center.
Adjusted operating expenses (including stock-based compensation but excluding amortization of acquisition-related intangibles) increased 21.3% from the year-ago quarter to $1.352 billion.
This was primarily because of higher investments in research and development, marketing and sales, and general and administrative activities.
However, as a percentage of revenues, operating expenses contracted 320 bps to 70.6%.

Salesforce posted adjusted operating income (including stock-based compensation but excluding amortization of acquisition-related intangibles) of $89.6 million compared with the year-ago figure of $34.2 million, while operating margin improved 240 bps to 4.7%.
The year-over-year improvements in adjusted operating income and margin were mainly backed by a higher revenue base and a drop in operating expenses as a percentage of revenues.
Salesforce exited the first quarter with cash and cash equivalents, and marketable securities of $2.031 billion, compared with $1.341 billion in the previous quarter.
Accounts receivable were $1.193 billion compared with $2.496 million at the end of fourth-quarter fiscal 2016.
Total deferred revenue, as of Apr 30, 2016, was $4.01 billion, up 31% on a year-over-year basis.
During the quarter, the company generated record operating cash flow of $1.051 billion and free cash flow of $967.8 million.
Buoyed by the strong results, Salesforce raised its fiscal 2017 outlook.
The company now expects revenues in the range of $8.16 billion to $8.20 billion, up from the previous projection of $8.08-$8.12 billion, representing a 22-23% year-over-year increase.
The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $8.128 billion.
Similarly, non-GAAP earnings per share for fiscal 2017 are now projected to come between $1.00 and $1.02, up from the earlier guidance of 99 cents to $1.01.
The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at 36 cents.
Apart from providing an upbeat guidance for fiscal 2017, the company also issued an optimistic outlook for the second quarter.
Salesforce projects second-quarter revenues between $2.005 billion and $2.015 billion, representing a 23% year-over-year increase.
The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $1.983 billion.
The company expects non-GAAP earnings per share in the 24-25 cents band.
The Zacks Consensus Estimate stands at 9 cents.
Salesforce started fiscal 2017 on a strong note with better-than-expected top-line results, which also improved significantly year over year.
The robust revenues were primarily backed by growth across all its business segments and the Salesforce ExactTarget Marketing Cloud platform.
Bottom-line results also improved significantly and matched the Zacks Consensus Estimate.
Moreover, the company provided an optimistic second quarter outlook and raised fiscal 2017 guidance.
The higher number of deal wins and geographical contributions were also encouraging.
We consider the rapid adoption of Salesforce1 Customer Platform to be a positive.
Overall, the company's diverse cloud offerings and considerable spending on digital marketing remain the catalysts.
Moreover, strategic acquisitions and the resultant synergies are expected to benefit over the long run.
In view of increasing customer adoption and satisfactory performances, market research firm Gartner acknowledged Salesforce as the leading social CRM solution provider.
We believe that the rapid adoption of Salesforce's platforms indicate solid growth opportunities in the ever-growing cloud computing segment.

Although the company is growing reasonably in the cloud market, growth prospects have been rationalized to a considerable extent due to intensifying competition from International Business Machines IBM , Oracle Corp. ORCL and SAP AG.
Moreover, currency fluctuations and stepped-up investments in international expansions and data centers could impact near-term results.
